ACR Summary: Screen reader users experience challenges accessing image descriptions, alternative text, and tabular data due to missing or inadequate alt text, CSS markers, and media content support within various Drupal components.  This impacts content comprehension and usability.

Users relying on screen readers experience difficulty accessing multimedia content due to inaccessible HTML tracks and audio/video track navigation, impacting content understanding and customization options. Lack of readily available and manageable transcripts presents a barrier for users with hearing impairments.

The manifest.json file generation process requires attention to ensure sufficient alternative descriptions and labels are provided for screen reader users, as this file is critical for assistive technology interpretation.

The product currently exhibits accessibility barriers impacting autocomplete functionality. Specifically, a replacement of a jQuery UI component introduces potential accessibility issues and IME users on Android may experience search interruptions.

Multiple open issues indicate accessibility barriers related to taxonomy navigation, error messaging, content presentation, icon labeling, sorting, and UI interactions. These issues could negatively impact users with disabilities’ ability to effectively utilize key functionality.

Multiple issues indicate potential barriers to accessibility for users of this product. Concerns include persistent Inline Form Error displays, layout disruptions with text resizing, challenges with tabular data interpretation, magnification issues, disrupted sub-menu navigation, and overlapping content on small screens.

Multiple accessibility barriers exist related to insufficient color contrast, inadequate button size, and unclear UI elements impacting users with low vision and those utilizing assistive technology. These issues affect functionality across various components, requiring further investigation.

Users relying on screen readers may experience difficulty accessing content within off-canvas dialogs due to inadequate focus management and keyboard navigation, impacting understanding and interaction.
The link panel’s potential contrast issue may present a barrier for users with low vision, impacting their ability to distinguish links and navigate the website effectively.

Users may experience difficulty navigating hierarchical select lists and activating shortcut action links due to limited visual hierarchy and available space, potentially impeding selection and interaction.

Multiple open issues indicate significant accessibility barriers impacting keyboard navigation, screen reader users, and interactions with menus, tooltips, and datepickers. Users may experience difficulty navigating away from toolbar sub-menus using a keyboard, potentially impeding task completion and access to other application features.

Users who prefer reduced motion may experience distraction or disorientation due to animations, potentially causing discomfort and difficulty. The product’s current implementation lacks support for this user preference, creating a barrier.

The system’s reliance on animations and transitions presents a potential barrier for users sensitive to motion. Specifically, the website’s behavior may conflict with user-configured “reduce motion” settings and the system lacks a mechanism to reduce or disable animation effects.

The website exhibits accessibility barriers, specifically a focus trap issue impacting keyboard navigation and a horizontal scrollbar issue within the media library dialog experienced with Windows high contrast mode. These issues present challenges for users with disabilities.

Page navigation and content comprehension are impaired due to insufficient contextual information provided by page titles and the lack of clear visual indicators for active workspaces. These issues impact screen reader users’ ability to effectively utilize the interface.

Users may experience barriers accessing functionality related to comments, links, and drop buttons. These issues require remediation to ensure full accessibility.
